turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Noah was my counselor in my freshman year.  That's probably where I got the idea for the icepick.  For my book. Funny how the subconscious works.  Hazel is my friend.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: She wiped out her whole family.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Yes.  She's helped me understand homicidal impulse.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Didn't you study it in school?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Only in theory.  You know all about homicidal impulse, don't you, shooter?  Not in theory -- in practice.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: What happened, Nick?  Did you get sucked into it? Did you like it too much?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I didn't.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Yes, you did.  They never tested you, did they?  But Internal Affairs knew.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: How exactly did you hear?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I have attorneys.  They have friends.  I have friends.  Money buys you a lot of attorneys and friends.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I don't know about that I don't have any money I don't have any attorneys Gus is my only real friend.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I wasn't talking about real friends. Why doesn't Gus like me.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I like you.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Do you?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Yeah.  Would you like to come up and have a drink?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: You're not easy to figure.  I'm just very good at figuring.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Don't get too cocky.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: You can make a mistake.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Not me.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Jack Daniel's okay?  It's gonna have to be.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Ice?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Please.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What did you pay Nilsen?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Isn't he the policeman that you shot, Shooter?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What if I asked you not to call me Shooter?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: What if I call you Nicky?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: My wife used to call me that.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I know, Nicky, but I like it.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Cheers.  My friends call me Catherine.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What did Bobby Vasquez used to call you?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Bitch mostly, but he meant it affectionately.  You don't have any coke, do you?  I love coke and Jack Daniel's.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: There's Pepsi in the fridge.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: It's not the same thing, is it?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Say -- "What do you want from me, Catherine?"

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What do you want from me, Catherine?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Aren't you going to thank me?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What's it about?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: A boy kills his parents.  They have a plane.  He makes it look like an accident.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Why does he do it?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: To see if he can get away with it.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: When did you write it?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: You mean did I write it before my parents died?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: No.  I wrote it years afterwards.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: You're not going to stop following me around now just because you're on leave -- are you?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Good.  I'd miss you.  You can get into trouble, though. You're not really a cop anymore.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I'll risk it.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Why take the risk?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: To see if I can get away with it.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: How's your new book?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I'm getting deeper and deeper into my character.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I'm leaving the house around midnight.  In case you're going to follow me.  I'm going down to Johnny's club.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I'll meet you there.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Maybe she saw something she didn't see before.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: She's seen everything before.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Did you think it was so special?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I told her it was the fuck of the century.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What did you think?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I thought it was a pretty good beginning.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: How about Roxy?  Is she a fuck to the century, too?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Do you want her to join us sometime?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: How's your shoulder?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Fine.  How's your back?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: It hurts.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Are you kidding?  You think this is my idea of morning-after conversation?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Do you want personal insights and adolescent secrets?  I don't do those.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I thought that business with the scarf was pretty nifty.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I told you I had a vivid imagination.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: You shouldn't play this game.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I don't have a choice.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: You're in over your head.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I should have known.  I came into the house when you were down on the beach.  She looked at me so strangely.  She left right after you.  I shouldn't have let her watch us. She wanted to watch me all the time.  She tried to kill you, didn't she?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Did you like her to watch?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Do you think I told her to kill You?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Everybody that I care about dies.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: It's OK.  It's OK.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Make love to me.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Do you think she killed Johnny Boz?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: For what... to set me up?  She loved me she wouldn't frame me.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Maybe she got jealous of Johnny Boz, too.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: No, she didn't... she never got jealous before... she got excited.  I don't have luck with women. There was this girl I met while I was in college.  I slept with her once.  She started following me around, taking my picture.  She dyed her hair, copied my clothes. Lisa something... Oberman.  It was awful.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I thought you didn't do adolescent secrets.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I never have before.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: No?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: No more games, Nick.  I'm tired of playing games!

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: You won't believe me.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Try me.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I paid him $50,000 in cash for your psychiatric file.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: About three months before I met you.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I'd read about your shootings in the papers.  I decided to write a book about a detective.  I wanted to know my character.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: You paid $50,000 for your character?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I would've paid more.  I wanted to know everything about you.  Then you came down here after Johnny got killed... it gave me a chance to get to know my character better.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What about the other night. What about last night?  Was that to get to know your character?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Maybe I'm losing interest in my book.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Do you believe me?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I'll convince you.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: What did he say?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: He asked if I had an icepick in me yet.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Funny.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Can I talk to you a minute?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Honey, why don't you go in the car?  I'll be right there.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: You like to hang out with murderers or what?  Did you know Roxy --

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Of course I knew.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I just thought I'd surprise you.  What's the matter?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I found Lisa Henderson.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Did you?  What's she doing?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: You're not going to tell me what she's doing.  I thought we weren't playing games anymore.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I did, too.  She told me it was backwards -- she said you even styled your hair the way she did.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: You still think I kill people, don't you?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Liar.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: How'd you get in here?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I decided to give you one more chance.  I missed you.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: You didn't not see me long enough to miss me.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Did you miss me?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Come over here and tell me no.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I have to do some research tomorrow.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I'm very good at research.  I'll help you.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: No thanks.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: What are you researching?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I'm writing a book.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Really.  What are you writing about.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: A detective.  He falls for the wrong girl.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: What happens to them?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: They fuck like minks, raise rugrats, and live happily ever after.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: It won't sell.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Somebody has to die.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Somebody always does.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I finished my book.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: How did it end?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I told you.  She kills him.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: What do you want, Nick?  Flowers? I'll send you some flowers.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What is this -- some kind of... Joke?  Are we playing games again?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: The games are over.  You were right. It was the fuck of the century, Shooter.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: What do we do now, Nick?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: We fuck like minks.  We raise rugrats.  We live happily ever after.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I hate rugrats.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: We fuck like minks.  We forget the rugrats.  We live happily ever after.

turns.speaker: CORRIGAN
turns.text: I'm John Corrigan.  I'm an assistant district attorney, Ms.  Tramell. Can we get you anything?  Would you like some coffee?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: No thank you.

turns.speaker: CORRIGAN
turns.text: There is no smoking in this building, Ms. Tramell.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: What are you going to do?  Charge me with smoking?

turns.speaker: CORRIGAN
turns.text: Would you tell us the nature of your relationship with Mr. Boz?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I had sex with him for about a year and a half.  I liked having sex with him.

turns.speaker: CORRIGAN
turns.text: Did you ever engage in sado- masochistic activity with him?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Exactly what do you have in mind, Mr. Corrigan.

turns.speaker: CORRIGAN
turns.text: Did you ever tie him up?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: CORRIGAN
turns.text: Did you kill Mr. Boz, Ms. Tramell?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I'd have to be pretty stupid to write a book about a killing and then kill him the way I described in my book. I'd be announcing myself as the killer.  I'm not stupid.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: How did he die?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: He was murdered.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Really.  Maybe that's why you're from Homicide.  How?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I don't really feel like talking anymore.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Listen, lady, we can do this downtown if you --

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Read me my rights and arrest me and I'll go downtown.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: You have the right to an attorney.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Why would I need an attorney?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: You workin' on another book?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Yes I am.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: It must really be somehtin' --makin' stuff up all the time.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: It teaches you to lie.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: How's that?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: You make it up, but it has to be believable.  They call it suspension of disbelief.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: I like that.  "Suspension of Disbelief."

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: The answer is no.  I didn't kill him.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Do you use drugs, Ms. Tramell?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Sometimes.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: What kind of drugs?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Cocaine.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: In the beginning.  Then I got to like what he did for me.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: That's pretty cold, ain't it, lady?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I'm a writer,  I use people for what I write.  You write what you know.  Let the world beware.

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE
turns.text: He was walking home from work. They only lived a coupla blocks from the clinic.  Somebody drove by and shot him.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What was the weapon?

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE
turns.text: .38 revolver.  Never recovered.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Were there ever any suspects?

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE
turns.text: No suspects, no motive.  Unsolved.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Was his wife ever a suspect?

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE
turns.text: I had another one of you guys down here from Frisco -- about a year ago -- he asked me the same question.  What's this about anyway?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Routine.

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE
turns.text: Yeah, he said it was routine too. Now it's two guys saying it's routine.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Do you remember his name?

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE
turns.text: Nope, can't say that I do.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Nilsen?

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE
turns.text: That's him.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Was she ever a suspect?

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE
turns.text: Nope.  There was some talk; it never panned.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What kind of talk?

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE
turns.text: The usual -- a girlfriend.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: He had a girlfriend?

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE
turns.text: Nope. She did.  Like I say.  It never panned.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: DETECTIVE
turns.text: I hope I helped you out.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: You did.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Who was this fuckin' guy?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Rock and roll, Gus.  Johnny Boz.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: I never heard of him.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Before your time, pop.  Mid-sixties.  Five or six hits. He's got a club down in the Fillmore now.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Not now he don't.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Talcott doesn't usually show up at the office 'till after his 18 holes. What are they nervous about?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: They're executives.  They're nervous about everything.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Ain't that cute?  They got his and her Pig-assos, son.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I didn't know you knew who Picasso was, Gus.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: I'm a smart sonofabitch.  I just hide it.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: How'd it go, son?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: She misses me.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Hallelujah.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: What you doin', son?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: It's my first drink in three months. That okay with you, pop?  She doesn't know me.  I never saw her before Gus and I talked to her.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Ain't you go nothin' better to do than to come in here and jack off the damn machine?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What are you doing here, Pop?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: I came in here to jack off the damn machine.  One dead psychology professor. Noah Goldstein.  Dr. Noah Goldstein. And guess what?  He was her counselor.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Was she ever suspect?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: No, sir.  They never even got a statement from her.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Do you remember a case -- 1956 -- Hazel Dobkins?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Hell yes!  Couldn't get it outta my head for years.  Still can't. Nice little kids -- nice husband, wasn't porkin' around -- no financial problems.  One day -- outta the clear blue sky -- she does 'em.  All of 'em.  Used a knife. He got for a wedding present. Didn't even deny it.  Sweet as honey.  Said she didn't know why she done it.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: What's goin' down, son?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Nothin'  I'll be okay, pop.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: No, sir.  You won't.  There's smoke off yonder on the horizon.  They're gonna want your badge.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I got tired of being played with.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: You sure got real conclusive ways of demonstrating that.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: She knows where I live and breathe. She's coming after me.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: What is it you got between you?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Somethin', though.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: You think I --

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: I don't son, but I got the minority opinion.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I don't think it's funny.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Well, hell, son, it's got a certain ring to it, I'll say that.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Forgive me for askin', son, and I don't mean to belabor the obvious, but why is it that you've got your head so far up your own ass?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: She want to play?  Fine.  I can play.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Everybody that she plays with dies.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I know what that's like.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Easy there, partner -- I wasn't there.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: I went over last night, too.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I wasn't there last night, either.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: You... fucked her!  Goddamn dumb sonofabitch... You fucked her! Goddamn, you are one dumb sonofabitch --

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I'm not gonna get AIDS, pop --don't worry about it.  I always use a rubber.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: I don't give a... flyin'... chili- bean... fart about AIDS!

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: You oughta use a rubber, pop.  You really should.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: What in the hell for?  You think I'm gettin' any at my age?  I don't like blue-haired women.  I don't like 'em.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: You don't like punk rockers?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Say what?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: You feeling better?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: I feel fine!

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I'm not afraid of her.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Why the hell not?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I don't know.  I'm just not.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: That's her pussy talkin' --He gets a real nasty look from a very fat woman eating a cheeseburger.  He winks at her.  The woman looks away from him, shaking her head.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: It doesn't make sense.  She didn't know me three months ago.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Maybe it wasn't her that paid him. Maybe the money was for somethin' else.  How the fuck do I know? I'm just an old city cowboy tryin' not to fall outta his saddle.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: You all right, pop?  You want me to drive you?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: In that little pissant car of yours? Hell, no.  I ain't gettin' no back pain disability retirement -- I'm gettin' me a full pension and a real gold-plate Seiko watch.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Come on, I'll drive you in this thing.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: You think I'd let you drive my Cadillac car?  I ain't lettin' no hear-up-his-ass person drive my Cadillac car.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Catherine says you don't like her.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: She's right.  You got an icepick in you yet?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: You know that stuff they say about how you can judge people by their friends?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I don't believe it.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: You're my friend, Gus.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I don't understand what the hell's going on here, pop.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Ain't that hard, son.  This young farmgirl, she got tired of all that attention goin' to her little brothers -- she fixed 'em.  Just like 'ole Hazel Dobkins fixed her whole family -- except young Roxy here, she didn't use a wedding present.  She used Daddy's razor.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I'm not sure anymore she did it.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Which one you talkin' about now, son?  We know ole Hazel did it; we know young Roxy did it -- and the other one Well, hell, she's got that magna come lawdy pussy on her that done fried up your brain.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: So Nilsen had a report on her -- so what.  You don't know what the hell was in it?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Catherine told me what was in it.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: If she's telling  you the truth.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Don't you get it, Gus?  If Beth killed Johnny Boz to frame Catherine -- she wouldn't want anyone to know what happened at Berkeley.  It gives her the motive to kill Nilsen.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: How did she know Nilsen knew about it -- if it happened?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: He was I.A.  He probably asked her about it.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: She'd have to be nuttier than a twenty-pound Christmas fruitcake. She's not the one who hangs out with multiple murderers -- your girlfriend is.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: She's a writer -- it's part of what she does.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Goddamn writers -- all they do is use up trees and ruin people's eyes.  There's gotta be somebody at Berkeley who knows what the hell happened.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I know what happened.  Catherine told me what happened.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: You got goddamn tweety-birds flutterin' around your head, that's what you got.  You think you're gonna fuck like minks, raise rugrats, and live happily ever after?  Oh, man.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Where the hell you goin'?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I'm going with you.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: She said alone -- suite 405.  It ain't gonna take long.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Maybe the maid did it.

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: She's 54 years old and weighs 240 pounds.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Not unless she got up in the ring and turned into one mean sonofabitch.

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: Maybe she did, Gus.  Maybe she grew herself an Afro and learned a left hook and put shoe polish on her face.  Let's polygraph her again and ask her about it.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Maybe it's for old-time's sake.

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: Sometimes I think he started banging her just to get himself off the hook with Internal Affairs.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: He ain't that way.  He's got heart.

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: Yeah.  I know.

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: You look like dogshit.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: He looks a little shrunk, that's all.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: You're already gettin' psychological input, son.

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: Go stick your head in a tub of ice water.  See where she leads.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Homicide.

turns.speaker: THE WOMAN
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: When was the last time you saw John Boz?

turns.speaker: THE WOMAN
turns.text: Is he dead?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Were you with him last night?

turns.speaker: THE WOMAN
turns.text: You're looking for Catherine, not me.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: What was the motive?

turns.speaker: THE WOMAN
turns.text: She said she didn't know herself, just sort of did it on impulse.  The razor just happened to be there.

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: He left the club with his girlfriend about midnight.  That's the last time anybody saw him.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What was it?

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: Keep your three o'clock.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Do you want me to work the case, Phil, or do you want me to --

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: I said keep it.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Are you kidding me?

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: Formerly engaged to Roberto Vasquez, deceased --

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I love it.  She's got a hundred million bucks.  She fucks fighters and rock and roll stars.  And she's got a degree in screwing with peoples' heads.

turns.speaker: LT. WALKER
turns.text: You forgot her degree in literature. She's a writer.  She published a novel last year under a pen name. Do you want to know what it's about?
